title: 'The Crown,' 'Ted Lasso' Rule at Emmys
text:
Netflix also prevailed in one of the most closely watched races in the industry, winning outstanding limited series with "The Queen's Gambit," which broke out in the depths of the pandemic and sent fans scrambling to buy chess sets.

The streaming service had never before won a major series-level Emmy since first breaking into the Emmys eight years ago with "House of Cards."

Those long-awaited victories were juxtaposed with Apple's relatively quick sprint to the winner's circle. Less than two years after the launch of Apple TV+, the streamer seized the award for outstanding comedy series, thanks to "Ted Lasso." In his acceptance speech, executive producer Bill Lawrence jokingly thanked "T-Dog, my new nickname for Tim Cook," Apple's CEO.

The warmhearted sports comedy scored across the genre, with wins for lead actor Jason Sudeikis, supporting actress Hannah Waddingham and supporting actor Brett Goldstein, who was up against three of his fellow "Ted Lasso" castmates in that category.

In the first year of eligibility for its original series, streaming service HBO Max got on the board with "Hacks." The comedy about a Las Vegas comedian (Jean Smart) and her reluctant millennial protegee (Hannah Einbinder) earned Ms. Smart the first lead-actress win of her career -- and one of the loudest ovations of the evening. "Hacks" was also honored for its directing and the writing of series co-creators Lucia Aniello, Paul W. Downs and Jen Statsky.

"Mare of Easttown," HBO's addictive crime drama, fell short of winning best limited series, but racked up awards for lead actress Kate Winslet, along with supporting actors Julianne Nicholson and Evan Peters.

As the score for industry winners and losers emerged Sunday, with basic cable and broadcast networks shut out of many top categories, TV fans got a showcase for the series and performers that helped many people get through the pandemic.

"The Crown" swept the acting categories among dramas with wins for lead actress Olivia Colman (in her final run on the series as Queen Elizabeth II); lead actor Josh O'Connor (as Prince Charles); supporting actress Gillian Anderson (as Margaret Thatcher); and Tobias Menzies (as Prince Philip). The show's behind-the-scene winners were series writer Peter Morgan and director Jessica Hobbs.

Michaela Coel, the creator of HBO's "I May Destroy You," a kaleidoscopic sexual assault drama, accepted the award for writing in a limited series and directed her message at fellow writers, saying, "Write the tales that scare you."

In other categories, "Last Week Tonight With John Oliver" won for best variety talk series, its sixth year in a row. The first person the host thanked was fellow nominee Conan O'Brien, who in June ended his run on late-night TV after 28 years. "RuPaul's Drag Race" extended its winning streak, too, winning outstanding competition program for a fourth year in a row.
